comment._content: Is it possible to run in a skirt like that?

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/la_belle_province] Aha! Wondering if anyone else would ponder that, but if you look closely, there's a (buttoned?) seam up the middle of each skirt. I'm assuming that they increased mobility by judicious unbuttoning...

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: So risque! But they were called hobble skirts for a reason...

comment.author: 11783425@N07

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Apropos your last comment in those skirts they couldn't catch up with my Granny?  Then again my Granny would have been well able to run herseld in those days!  It really is a pity that they were a camogie team, all the wonderful puns lost as a result.

comment.author: 23085117@N00
comment._content: Looks like "Dutch Crops" or "Catch Crops" on the sign up above. I guess the photographer didn't want ads without product placement $.

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: Playing short? Only 14 women.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Is it 14 or 15? Never played...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] I can say I'd never heard of the game until I saw this great pic.  A quick read of the Wikipedia article and I learned that teams are 15 a side.  But a deeper read shows that prior to 1999 teams had only 12 to the side (and played on smaller fields) so . . . I was mistook. They're not playing short at all.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Never heard of hockey?! You haven't lived until you've experienced a women's hockey team thundering down a field at you (didn't play, but we shared facilities in school)! Makes a cattle stampede look like a tea party...

As to the numbers, thanks for doing all the work. I tried searches, but there are so many forms - ice, etc. - that to my shame, I had given up. So we have a full team here, plus some subs presumably.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: NLI either you've been nipping on the Christmas sherry(which will make me very cross 'cause I wanted it for the trifle) our you're cracking up with all this CSI stuff?  We began with CAMOGIE not hockey and that's the game Seuss never heard of!!!  Hockey is played with 11 a side just like soccer.  Camogie as I remember it was played 13 a side but that may be wrong.  What I do remember of it was that the skill level was dire and the standard at the moment is light years ahead of anything on offer 40, 30 or even 20 years ago.  I watched a recent Camogie final and the ladies would give many a hurling team a run for their money!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Crikey, better not have any more hot ports! Purely medicinal, of course, very bad cold! It's the memory of Miss HOOKEY that shemozzled me. Just cannot get the wish out of my head that this would have been Miss Hookey's hockey team...  :D
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I have to say that I agree with the lovely La Belle our Canadian cousin it is a great pleasure to follow a photostream from a National Library and find it refreshing, entertaining, educational and challenging.  Most of that is due to you Carol and your terrific sense of humour.  Take a bow young lady, if you had been playing for Ms. Hookey's hockey team you'd have been playing a blinder!

comment.author: 90012953@N07
comment._content: The Miss Hookey in this photo is Monica (seated on the ground on the left). She lived at 1 Bank Lane, Waterford. She died in Welling Kent in 1977. She was my grand Aunt.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90012953@N07] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Another cracked case for NLI and Carol.  Well done CJ and thank you for identifying the lovely lady.  This adds nicely to the fund of knowledge.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90012953@N07] Thanks so much for identifying "our Miss Hookey". It's lovely to know definitely which one she was. How did you come across this photo?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I think it's time to dust off another "People Identified" tag, don't you?  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Indeed and it is very nice to be able to identify which is Monica after all these years.  They say you are only dead when you are forgotten and now Monica has a whole lot of people who remember her as well as her relatives!

comment.author: 90012953@N07
comment._content: I just googled HOOKEY, which I do from time to time, just to see what comes up.I wasn't expecting to find such a brilliant photo.I didn't realize she had such a fan club either. Sorry I can't identify anybody else, but I'd bet the girl seated front centre was the full back!!

comment.author: 90012953@N07
comment._content: The  Studio stamp is of Hughes Waterford and Dungarvan. Writen by hand on the back is 25-December 1915. Happy Christmas. So she was using them as christmas cards. I've posted more Hookey photos in my Photostream
